translated: Composed by Venerable Vasubandhu
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order
What is the meaning of ignorance?
It means the essence is not clear.
If so, ignorance should be the eyes and so forth.
If so, this meaning should be called the absence of clarity.
If so, the essence of ignorance should not exist.
In order to show that the meaning of having an essence does not overlap with other things, the verse says:
The opposite of clarity is ignorance, like non-friend and non-real, etc.
The treatise says:
Like the enemies that oppose close friends, the opposite of close friends is called non-friend, not different from friends, not the absence of friends.
Truthful speech is called real, and the opposite of this, deceptive speech, is called non-real, not different from real, also not the absence of real.
The word etc. is used to show that non-Dharma and non-meaning, the nature of non-events, etc., are not different and not absent.
In this way, ignorance has a separate real essence, which is the opposite of clarity, not different and not absent.
How do we know this?
Because it is said to be the condition for formations.
There is also a more compelling proof.
A verse says:
Because it is said to be bonds, etc., because it is not evil wisdom or views,
Because it is associated with views, and because it is said to defile wisdom.
The treatise says:

The sutras say that ignorance is bonds, fetters, latent tendencies, outflows, yokes, floods, and so on. It cannot be said that the other faculties such as the eye, or the complete absence of a substance, are the things called bonds, fetters, and so on. Therefore there is a separate dharma called ignorance.
Just as evil wives and children are called having no wives and children, so evil wisdom should be called ignorance. It is not ignorance because it has views.
All defiled wisdom is called evil wisdom. Because there are views within it, it is not ignorance.
If that is so, then non-seeing wisdom should be accepted as ignorance.
No, because ignorance is associated with views.
If ignorance were wisdom, it should not be associated with views, because two wisdoms do not coexist in association.
Also, it is said that ignorance can defile discernment, as a scripture says:
â€œCraving defiles the mind and prevents liberation, while ignorance defiles discernment and prevents purity. Discernment cannot defile discernment itself.
Just as craving, which is of a different class, can defile the mind.
Ignorance, which is also different from discernment, can defile it. Why not allow this?

Defiled discernment is mixed with good discernment and makes it impure, and it is said to defile it, just as craving defiles the mind and prevents liberation. How can it be said to defile the mind unless it actually occurs and is associated with the mind?
However, by the power of craving, the mind is damaged and bound and prevented from liberation. Later, when the perfuming of that craving is eliminated, the mind is liberated.
In the same way, ignorance defiles discernment and prevents purity, but it is not associated with discernment. It only damages and pollutes discernment.
What principle contradicts this analysis? Who can deny what one analyzes for oneself?
However, there is a separate ignorance that is a class apart from discernment, just as craving is a class apart from mind. This explanation is good.
There is an opinion that all passions are ignorance. This also should be refuted by the same principle as above.

If all passions are ignorance, then ignorance should not be listed separately among the fetters, etc., nor should it be associated with views, etc., because views, etc., are not associated with themselves.
Or, it should be said that ignorance defiles mind. If it is said that this is a special case, then it should not be said that ignorance is a general term for defiled discernment.
Since it is admitted that ignorance has a substance that is a separate dharma, it should be explained what its characteristics are.
It is the non-understanding of the truths, actions, and their results.
It has not been determined what characteristics non-understanding has.
Is it different from understanding, or does it not exist?
Both alternatives have faults, as in the case of ignorance.
This means that it is a separate dharma that is the opposite of understanding.
This is also difficult to determine. What are its characteristics?
This kind of dharma should be explained in this way.
As stated elsewhere:
What is the eye?
It is the pure form that serves as the basis for eye consciousness.
Ignorance is also like this, only its function can be discerned.
The Venerable DharmatrÄta says that this ignorance is the nature of self-conceit of all sentient beings, different from the conceit of I am.
What is the substance of the nature of self-conceit?
A sÅ«tra says:

Now, having known and seen in this way, all craving, all views, all natures, all attachments to 'mine' and 'I am,' all conceit of 'I am,' and all latent tendencies are cut off and thoroughly known. Therefore, it is known that the nature of self-conceit is different from the conceit of 'I am.'
How do we know that the nature of self-conceit is precisely ignorance?
It cannot be said to be another affliction.
Why can it not be said to be another kind of conceit, etc.?
If we were to further investigate this in detail, the discussion would become too verbose, so we should stop here.
What is the meaning of name-and-form?
Form has been explained before, now we only explain name.
A verse says:
It is called the four aggregates of formless [dharmas].
The treatise says:
Why are the four aggregates of formless [dharmas] called name?
Because they transform in meaning according to the power of the names and objects of the faculties, they are called name.
How do they transform according to the power of names?
It means that according to the various names established by the world, they transform and express meaning, just like the names cow, horse, color, taste, etc.
For what reason is this again called name?
Because they transform and cognize objects here and there.
Also, because they are similar to names and manifest according to names.
Other masters say:
The four formless aggregates, having abandoned this body, transform and go to other lives, transforming like names, therefore they are called name.
What is the meaning of contact?
Verse:
Contact arises from the union of the six [faculties], three [objects], and [consciousness].
Treatise:
There are six kinds of contact, namely eye contact up to mind contact.
What is this again?
It is produced by the union of the three, that is, the faculty, the object, and consciousness, because a separate contact arises due to the union of the three.
As for the five contacts that arise, they can be united by the three, because it is accepted that the faculty, the object, and consciousness arise simultaneously.
The faculty of mind is past, the dharma is either future or present, and mental consciousness is present. How can they be united?
This is precisely what is meant by union, namely, the meaning of cause and effect is accomplished.
Or it is called union because they have the same effect, that is, because the three - faculty, object, and consciousness - equally give rise to contact.
The masters have different understandings of this.
Some say:
The union of the three is called contact.
They cite a sutra to prove this.
As a sutra says:
These three dharmas gathered and united are called contact.
Some say:
A separate dharma that is associated with the mind, produced by the union of the three, is called contact.
They cite a sutra to prove this.
The sutra says:
What are the six?
The six dharma gates:
First, the six internal sense bases;
Second, the six external sense bases;
Third, the six sense-organ bodies;
Fourth, the six contact bodies;
Fifth, the six feeling bodies;
Sixth, the six craving bodies.
In this scripture, contact is separately explained apart from the sense organs, sense objects, and consciousnesses. Therefore, contact exists separately.

As for the explanation that the coming together of the three is called contact, it explains the previously cited scripture of six sixes. It is not because of separate explanation that there is a separate substance.
Do not make the mistake of saying that feeling and craving are not included in the factor element, because apart from craving, feeling, and contact, there is no other substance of the factor element.

Your school does not explain apart from contact that there are three separately, but contact and the three are explained separately. Although there are sense organs and sense objects that do not give rise to consciousness, there is no consciousness that does not rely on sense organs and sense objects.
Therefore, having already explained the three, to separately explain contact again would be useless.
Others rescue by saying:
Not all eyes and forms are the causes of all eye consciousnesses. Not all eye consciousnesses are the effects of all eyes and forms.
Those that are not causes and effects are separately explained as the three. Those that are included as causes and effects are generally established as contact.
As for the explanation that apart from the three there is a separate contact, this explains the previously cited statement that the coming together and union of these three dharmas is called contact.

The scripture passage is different from this in the version of our school. Or, the result is metaphorically referred to as a cause, as in the statement that the appearance of buddhas in the world is a matter for rejoicing.
Such explanations of the scriptures by means of questions and answers are very numerous and we should stop here.
However, the Abhidharma masters say that there is a separate contact, and the above six contacts are combined into two.
A verse says:
The first five are called contact with resistance, and the sixth is called contact with discrimination.
The treatise says:
The first five contacts are called contact with resistance because they are based on the five material sense organs that have resistance.
The sixth contact of manas is called contact with discrimination.
The reason for this is that discrimination refers to names, and names are the objects of manas contact, which extends to all objects. Therefore it is called contact with discrimination.
For example, it is said that eye consciousness only cognizes blue but not that it is blue, while mental consciousness cognizes blue and also that it is blue, and therefore it is called long.
Therefore, contact associated with resistance is named according to its basis, while contact associated with discursive thought is established according to its object.
Some say:

Mental consciousness is able to turn to an object only when discursive thought is added, but the five consciousnesses are not like this. Therefore, mental consciousness alone is called discursive thought, and that associated with it is called contact associated with discursive thought.
Therefore, contact associated with resistance is named according to its basis, while contact associated with discursive thought is established according to its association.
The above six kinds of contact, according to their specific associations, are further divided into eight kinds.
The verse says:
Clear, unclear, and neither, pure, defiled, and the rest,
Associated with love and hatred, pleasure, etc., accord with the three feelings.
The treatise says:
Associated with clear, unclear, etc., they form three kinds: first, clear contact, second, unclear contact, third, neither clear nor unclear contact.
These three should be known as the contact associated with the pure, the defiled, and the other.
The other refers to the pure and the defiled other, that is, the good with outflows and the non-defiled and non-defined.

One part of the contact of ignorance arises frequently. Based on that, the two contacts of craving and hostility are established, because the propensities of craving and hostility are associated with it.
In general, all contacts are formed into three contacts:
1. contact that conforms to the feeling of pleasure, 2. contact that conforms to the feeling of suffering, 3. contact that conforms to the feeling that is neither pleasurable nor suffering.

These three are called conforming to feeling because they can attract feelings of pleasure, etc., because they are experienced by feelings of pleasure, etc., or because they can serve as the basis for the mode of activity of feeling.
How is contact experienced by feeling?
The mode of activity of feeling is extremely similar to contact, because feeling arises in dependence on contact.
In this way, they are combined into sixteen kinds of contact.
What is the meaning of feeling?
A verse says:
From this, six feelings arise, five belonging to the body and the other to the mind.
The treatise says:
From the six kinds of contact there arise six kinds of feeling, namely, feeling born of contact with eyes, etc., up to feeling born of contact with mind.
Among the six, the first five are called bodily feelings because they are supported by material organs.
Feeling born of contact with mind is called mental feeling because it is supported by mind alone.
Do feeling and contact arise together or does feeling arise later?
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say that they arise together, because contact and feeling are reciprocal causes of each other.
How can two dharmas arise together?
The meaning of one producing the other can be established.
Why is this not established?
Because one dharma has no power over another dharma that has already been produced.
This is no different from the proposition that two dharmas arise together and the meaning of one producing the other is not established.
The meaning of one dharma having no power over another that has already been produced is the same as the previous meaning. What is the use of repeating it?
If this is so, then there is the error of mutual production.
We admit this, but it is not an error.
Our school maintains that the two are coexistent causes and are also reciprocal fruits.
Although you admit this, you do not admit that these two are reciprocal causes and fruits in the scriptures.
The scriptures only say:
Eye contact as a condition gives rise to feeling born from eye contact.
There is never a scripture that says: Eye feeling as a condition gives rise to contact born from eye feeling.
Moreover, this meaning is unreasonable because it goes beyond the dharmas that can give rise to it.
If a dharma is established as being able to give rise to that dharma, then these two are established as being temporally distinct.
For example, seed comes before sprout, milk comes before curd, striking comes before sound, and mind comes before consciousness, etc. Cause comes before effect, and this is well established.
There are also well-established simultaneous causes and effects, such as eye consciousness, etc., which occur together with eye and form, etc.
The four great elements occur together with the derivative form they produce. This is also accepted. The previous faculties and objects as conditions can give rise to the subsequent consciousness.
The previous aggregate of the great elements produces the subsequent derivative form. What principle can prevent this?
How can it be that the shadow and the body are not simultaneous?
Some say:

Feeling arises after contact. The sense faculty and object come first, then consciousness arises. The combination of these three is called contact. In the third moment, feeling arises in dependence on contact.
If this is so, then there should be consciousness that is not all feeling, and all consciousness should not be contact.
There is no such fault.

Because of the contact in the previous stage, feeling arises in the subsequent stage of contact. Therefore, at all times of contact there is feeling, and the substance of all consciousness is not apart from contact.
This is unreasonable.
What contradicts reason?
That is, sometimes the objects of the two contacts are different. Feeling in the previous stage of contact gives rise to feeling in the subsequent stage of contact.
How can feeling with a different object arise from contact with a different object?
Or it should be admitted that feeling is associated with this mind, but it does not have the same object as this mind.
If this is so, then if contact is established, there is consciousness that is contact but not feeling.
Prior to this stage, there is consciousness and feeling, but the substance is not contact, because the conditions are different.
What fault is there in this?
If so, then it would destroy the ten great mental factors, which are definitely always present in all mental states.
On what teaching are they definitely always present based?
They are based on the fundamental treatise.
We only take the sutras as authoritative, and the fundamental treatise is not authoritative. What fault is there in destroying it?
Therefore the World-Honored One said:
One should rely on the sutras as authoritative.
Or the meaning of the great mental factors is not necessarily universal to all minds.
If so, what is the meaning of the great mental factors?
There are three levels:
The first is the level with investigation and analysis, the second is the level without investigation but only analysis, and the third is the level without investigation or analysis.
There are also three levels:
The first is the wholesome level, the second is the unwholesome level, and the third is the indeterminate level.
There are also three levels:
The first is the level of training, the second is the level of no-more-training, and the third is the level of neither training nor no-more-training.
If a dharma exists in all the stages mentioned above, it is called a universal dharma.ğŸ”½If a dharma exists only in the good stages, it is called a great good stage dharma.
If a dharma exists only in the defiled stages, it is called a great defiled stage dharma.
These dharmas arise in succession according to their respective functions, not all simultaneously.
Others say that these great bad stage dharmas were brought in during recitation and are an addition, not originally recited.
If feeling arises after contact, how does the sutra explain it?
As a sutra says:
The eye and form as conditions give rise to eye consciousness. The union of the three is contact, and feeling, conceptualization, and volition arise together.
It only says they arise together, not that they arise together with contact. What contradiction does this pose for our school that it needs to be explained?
Also, the word together is used for immediate succession, as a sutra says:
Practicing the mindfulness factor of awakening together with loving-kindness.
Therefore, that is not evidence.
If that is so, why does a sutra say:
This is feeling, this is conceptualization, this is volition, this is consciousness. These dharmas are mixed and not separate, therefore there is no consciousness separate from feeling, etc.
Now we should carefully consider, what is the meaning of being mixed?
This sÅ«tra also says:
All that is felt is thought, all that is thought is conceptualized, all that is conceptualized is cognized.
We are not yet clear about this, is it said in terms of the object-support or in terms of a single moment?
Because there is also such a statement of being mixed in the arising of life and heat together, we know by analogy that this statement is definitely in terms of a single moment.
Also, a sÅ«tra says: The coming together of the three is contact. How can there be consciousness that is not the coming together of the three?
Or is it the coming together of the three but not called contact?
Therefore one should definitely admit that all consciousnesses together are all contact, and all that is contact is all born together with feeling, etc.
The ancillary discussion is finished. We should now explain the main point.
Verse:
These are further divided into eighteen by the differences in mental activities.
The treatise says:
In the previous brief explanation of one type of feeling, it is further divided into eighteen by the differences in mental activities.
The word further indicates that this is based on the previous to give rise to the next.
What are these eighteen mental activities?
They are the six mental activities of joy, sorrow, and equanimity.
Why are they established as eighteen?
If they were established by their own nature, there should only be three, because the three of joy, sorrow, and equanimity differ in their own nature.
If they were established by association, there should only be one, because all are associated with the mind.
If they were established by their objects, there should only be six, because form and the other six objects are their objects.
They are established as eighteen by all three [criteria].
Among them, the fifteen mental activities with form and other objects are called non-mixed objects, because their objects are separate.
The three mental activities with dharmas are both types.
What is the meaning of the term mental activity?
It is said that joy, etc., are the proximate causes of the mind, because the mind often moves among objects.
There is an opinion that joy, etc., can be the proximate causes, because they cause the mind to often move among objects.
How is bodily sensation not a proximate cause of the mind?
It is not called proximate because it does not depend on the mind alone, and because it is devoid of discrimination, it also does not move.
Why is the faculty of pleasure of the realm of manas in the third trance state not included among the proximate causes of the mind?

It is said that because the first trance state is not associated with manas, there is no faculty of pleasure, and also because there is no proximate cause of the mind categorized as the faculty of pain that opposes it.
If the proximate causes of the mind are only of the realm of manas, why does a scripture say:
When the eye sees material objects, it produces the proximate cause of joy with regard to agreeable material objects, etc., as is explained at length in the scripture.
It is said that this is because the proximate causes of joy, etc., of the realm of manas are attracted by the five sense consciousnesses.
Just as the contemplation of impurity is attracted by visual consciousness, but this contemplation of impurity is categorized as the realm of manas only.
Also, that scripture says, â€œThe eye sees forms, etc.,â€ and therefore your objection is not valid.
If one generates joy, sorrow, or indifference after seeing, etc., but not through seeing, etc., this is also mental activity.
If this were not so, then in the realm of desire there would be no mental activity of the realm of form that has form, etc., as its object.
Also, in the realm of form there would be no mental activity that has the objects of smell, taste, and touch of the realm of desire as its object.

The words â€œseeing form, etc.â€ are spoken with reference to the most obvious cases. After seeing form, etc., one generates joy, sorrow, or indifference with regard to sound, etc., and this is also mental activity. This is said with reference to cases in which there is no confusion. The objects of the organs are established in this way.
Can form, etc., only generate one mental activity of joy, sorrow, or indifference?
Yes, with reference to a single mental continuum, but not with reference to the object.ğŸ”½How many of the mental activities are bound to the realm of desire?
How many of the mental activities of the realm of desire have what as their object?
The same question is asked with reference to the realms of form and of non-form.
The verse says,
The desire realm desires eighteen, the form realm twelve, the upper three,

The desire realm has eighteen [mental activities] that take the desire realm as their object. The form realm has twelve [mental activities] that take the form realm as their object. The upper two realms each have three [mental activities] that take the upper two realms as their objects.ğŸ”½The two [mental activities] that take the desire realm as their object have twelve [mental activities] that take the desire realm as their object. Eight [mental activities] take themselves as their object. Two [mental activities] take the formless realm as their object.

The two [mental activities] that take the upper two realms as their object have six [mental activities] that take the desire realm as their object. Four [mental activities] take themselves as their object. One [mental activity] takes the upper two realms as its object.
The preliminary stage of the first formless realm has four [mental activities] that take form as their object. One [mental activity] takes itself as its object.
The four fundamental [formless realms] and three adjacent [formless realms] have only one [mental activity] that takes itself as its object.
The treatise says:
The desire realm is bound to all eighteen [mental activities]. The number that take the desire realm as their object is also the same.
There are only twelve [mental activities] that take the form realm as their object, excluding the six of smell and taste, because they do not have objects.
There are only three [mental activities] that take the formless realm as their object, because they do not have the five objects such as form.
Having explained the bonds of the desire realm, we will now explain the bonds of the form realm.
The first two meditations only have twelve, excluding the six of sorrow.

There are also twelve [mental activities] that take the desire realm as their object, excluding the four of smell and taste. The remaining eight take themselves as their object. Two take the formless realm as their object, namely the mental activities of dharmas.
The four dhyanas are only six, that is, the four of equanimity and the two of joy and indifference, which take the desire realm as their object.
Excluding the two of smell and taste, the remaining four take themselves as their objects, and one takes the formless realm as its object, namely the dharma-conascent.
Having explained the attachment to the form realm, we will now explain the attachment to the formless realm.
The preliminary stage of the sphere of infinite space only has four kinds, namely the four of equanimity that only take form, sound, touch, and dharmas as their objects.
Taking the fourth dhyana as its object also has four kinds. This is said from the perspective of those who allow for separate objects.
If one grasps that stage as only generally taking the lower realms as its object, then there is only the dharma-conascent of mixed objects.

Taking the formless realm as its object is only one, namely the dharma-conascent of the four faculties. The fundamental stage and the three upper stages are only one, namely the dharma-conascent that only takes its own objects as its objects. Because the formless realm does not take the lower realms as its objects, and because the three upper stages do not take form as their objects.
The meaning of not taking the lower realms as objects will be explained later.
Are these mental activities also uncontaminated?
The verse states:
The eighteen are only contaminated.
The treatise states:
The eighteen are only impure because they are not associated with the pure mind and do not occur in the formless realm.
Who possesses how many of the various types of mental activities?
If one is born in the realm of desire and has not yet acquired a good mind of the realm of form, one possesses all of the mental activities of the realm of desire.
The first two trance states have eight, the third and fourth trance states have four, and the formless realm has one.
The mental activities of the upper realms that one possesses are all not associated with the lower realms, because they are only defiled.
If one has already acquired a good mind of the realm of form but has not yet eliminated desire, one possesses all of the mental activities of the realm of desire.
The first trance state has ten, and the rest are as explained above.
In the first trance state, one only possesses four kinds of joy, because the defiled mind does not take as objects smells and tastes of the lower realm.
One possesses all six kinds of indifference, because a good mind of the intermediate trance state can take as objects smells and tastes.
The rest should be understood according to this principle.
If one is born in the realm of form, one only possesses one indifference of the realm of desire, that associated with the mind of the path of liberation.
Some say that the VibhÄá¹£Ä masters established these mental activities according to their meaning.
However, I see that the meaning of the sÅ«tras is different.
Why is this?

One who has already attained freedom from the passions in a certain stage cannot generate mental activities with that stage as their object. Therefore the three of joy, sorrow, and indifference that are impure are not all included in mental activities.
Only those that are defiled and drag down the mind and frequently occur as objects are mental activities.
How do they drag down the mind?
Either through love, hatred, or indifference.

In order to counteract these, the Buddha taught the six kinds of constant abiding, which are seeing forms and not being joyful or sorrowful, with the mind constantly abiding in indifference, endowed with mindfulness and right knowledge, and so on, up to knowing dharmas in the same way.
Arhats are not without worldly joy in good dharmas, but this is said in order to stop defiled mental activities.
Also, these same joys, etc., are the thirty-six teachersâ€™ phrases, distinguished as being the basis for indulgence or liberation.
Because the great master has explained the distinctions of these phrases.
The basis of indulgence refers to defiled feelings.
The basis of renunciation refers to wholesome feelings.
Such feelings should be understood as included in the link of feeling.
Why are the remaining links of existence not explained, since there are innumerable distinctions in meaning?
Verse:
The rest have been explained or will be explained.
Commentary:
The remaining links of existence have either been explained or will be explained, so they are not discussed here.
Among them, the link of consciousness has already been explained as follows: Consciousness refers to each distinct cognition, which is also called the mental faculty, etc.
The link of the six sense bases has already been explained as follows: The basis of that consciousness, pure form, is called the five sense faculties such as the eye, etc.
The two links of karmic formations and becoming will be explained in the chapter on karma.
The two links of craving and grasping will be explained in the chapter on latent afflictions.
These links of dependent origination are briefly established as three: the factors of afflictions, karma, and the results of karmic maturation.
One should use an external analogy to illustrate their distinct functions.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
A verse says:
Here, afflictions are said to be like seeds, and also like dragons,
Like grass roots, tree trunks, and like rice wrapped in husks;
Karmic actions are like rice with husks, like medicinal herbs, like flowers;
The matter of retribution is like cooked food and drink.
The treatise says:
How are these three similar? Like sprouts, leaves, etc. are produced from seeds.
From afflictions, afflictions, karmic actions, and matters are produced. Like a dragon subduing a pond, the water is always inexhaustible.
Afflictions subdue karmic actions, producing and continuing without end. Like grass roots that have not been pulled out, the seedlings are cut but grow again.
If the roots of afflictions have not been pulled out, the destinies are extinguished but arise again. Like branches, flowers, and fruits are frequently produced from a tree trunk.
From the various afflictions, afflictions, karmic actions, and matters are repeatedly produced. Like rice wrapped in husks can produce sprouts, etc., it cannot produce them alone.
Or karmic actions wrapped in afflictions can attract other lives, it cannot attract them alone.
Afflictions should be known as being like seeds, etc.
Just as rice with its husk can produce sprouts, etc., so too karma with its afflictions can attract retribution.
Just as various plants and fruits ripen as their final stage, so too karma and its fruits ripen as their final stage, and no longer attract further retribution.
Just as a flower is the proximate cause of a fruit, so too karma is the proximate cause of the production of retribution.
Karma should be understood in the same way as rice, etc.
Just as cooked food is only to be enjoyed and cannot be transformed back into other food,
so too, once the matter of the retribution fruit has matured, it cannot attract further retribution for another life.
If the retribution of a certain life attracts further lives, and that further life attracts still further lives, then there would be no liberation.
The matter of the retribution fruit should be understood in the same way as cooked food.
Thus, the continuity of the arising of afflictions, karma, and matter in each life does not exceed four kinds of existence:
intermediate existence, birth existence, basic existence, and death existence, as explained above.
The meaning of defiled and undefiled, and the presence or absence in the three realms, will now be briefly discussed.
Verse:
Among the four kinds of existence, only the existence at birth is defiled.
Because of the passions of its own stage. The other three are of three kinds in the formless realm.
The treatise says:
Among the four kinds of existence, only the existence at birth is defiled.
By what passions?
By the passions of its own stage.
That is, birth in this stage is defiled by all the passions of this stage.
Therefore the Abhidharma masters all say:
There is not a single passion that lacks the power to moisten and unite with the existence at birth.
However, the union with existence is only due to the power of the passions, not to the power of the passions that appear as bonds and secondary passions.
Even though in this state the mind and body are dull and weak, still the passions appear due to the power of repeated appearance and recent activity.
You should know that the first moment of the intermediate state after death is also definitely defiled, just like the existence at birth.

However, the other three existences are of three kinds each. That is, the existences at the beginning, death, and in the intermediate state are each of the three kinds: good, defiled, and indeterminate.

In the formless realm, the three intermediate existences are excluded, because there is no spatial separation in that realm. In order to go to another place, intermediate existence can be established.
The verse does not mention the two realms of desire and form, therefore it is known that in those two realms, the four existences are all present.
The dependent origination of sentient beings has already been extensively analyzed. By what do all sentient beings abide?
Verse:
Sentient beings abide by means of food. The substance of the coarse food of the desire realm is only three.
Form cannot benefit, because it is liberated from its own faculties.
The three foods of contact, thought, and consciousness exist in the three realms with outflows.
The magically manifested body and the seeking of rebirth arise from smelling fragrance in the intermediate existence.
The first two benefit this world, the basis and what is based on it.
The latter two in the future existence, attracting and producing in sequence.ğŸ”½The treatise says:
The sutra says:
The World-Honored One himself realized and correctly awakened to, and correctly taught, one dharma, namely, that all sentient beings do not fail to abide by means of food.
What are the foods?
There are four kinds of nutriment:
1. gross physical nutriment, 2. contact, 3. mental volition, and 4. consciousness.
Gross physical nutriment is of two kinds: subtle and gross.
The subtle is the nutriment of the intermediate existence, because it is nourished by odors.
And the nutriment of the gods in the first eon is also subtle, because it does not become excrement, like sand moistened by oil, which enters the limbs.
Or, nutriment that is subtle and defiling, such as that of worms and infants, is called subtle, and the opposite of this is gross.
This kind of gross physical nutriment exists only in the realm of desire, because one is born in the upper realms free from craving for gross physical nutriment.
It is only the desire realm that is bound to gross physical nutriment.
The three of odor, taste, and touch are all the substance of gross physical nutriment, because they can be divided into parts and drunk or eaten, that is, received through the mouth or nose in parts.
How can light, shadow, flames, and coolness become nutriment?
It is said that this statement is made from the perspective of the majority.
Moreover, although they are not drunk or eaten, they can sustain the body and are also included in subtle nutriment, like anointing and washing.
Why is form not nutriment, even though it can be divided into parts and drunk or eaten?
Because it cannot benefit its own faculties, since it is liberated.
As for what is called food, it must first benefit one's own faculties and the great elements, and then extend to others.
When one sees and tastes form, it does not even benefit one's own faculties and the great elements, let alone being able to extend to others, because those faculties and objects are each separate.
When one sees form and gives rise to joy and pleasure, it is the contact that arises from form that is the food, not the form itself.
Moreover, non-returners and arhats who are liberated from craving for food, although they see various kinds of excellent food and drink, it does not benefit them.

Contact refers to the various contacts that arise from the union of the three [faculties, object, and consciousness]. Volition refers to mental action. Consciousness refers to the aggregate of consciousness. These three are only contaminated and are found in all three realms.
How is the essence of food not found in the uncontaminated?
VaibhÄá¹£ika masters give the following explanation:
The meaning of food is that which can nourish existence. The uncontaminated arises through cultivation in order to extinguish existence.
Moreover, a scripture says:
There are four kinds of food that can make sentient beings who have already been born abide and can nourish those seeking birth.
The pure [four foods] are not like this, so they are not the substance of food.
The term already born indicates the meaning of having already been born, as all those who have already been born in the various destinies are called already born.
What is the meaning of seeking birth?
This refers to the intermediate state, because the Buddha has used five names to refer to the intermediate state.
What are the five?
First, it is called mind-made, because it arises from the mind, not from external conditions such as semen and blood.
Second, it is called seeking birth, because it always delights in investigating the place of future birth.
Third, it is called eating smells, because it uses smells as food to nourish the body and go to the place of birth.
Fourth, it is called the intermediate state, because it is the aggregates that exist in the middle between the two destinies.
Fifth, it is called arising, because it temporarily arises facing the future birth.
As a sutra says:
There is arising that destroys the self, and there is arising that produces the world.
Arising refers to the intermediate state.
Also, a scripture says:
There is a person who has already severed the fetters of arising but has not yet severed the fetters of birth.
In this scripture, four sentences are extensively explained:

Those who are free from craving for the two realms and are of the upper stream are the first sentence, those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state are the second sentence, all arhats are the third sentence, and those who are excluded from the above characteristics are the fourth sentence.
Also, those who are many refer to arhats, and those who have craving are called those who seek birth.
How many kinds of food can make the many abide?
How many kinds of food benefit sentient beings who seek birth?
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say that all have four.

Those who have craving are also benefited by the condition of the food of form, which causes them to attract future existence, because the World-Honored One said that the four foods are all the conditions for illness, boils, arrows, and old age and death.
It is also seen that the food of thought makes the present body abide in peace.
There is a saying in the world:
In the past, there was a father who, during a time of famine, wanted to go to another place.

Since he himself was hungry and weak, and the two children were still young, he wanted to take them away but was physically unable to do so. He put some ash in a bag, hung it on the wall, and comforted the two children, saying it was a bag of flour.
The two children hoped for a long time, prolonging their lives. Later, someone came and opened the bag. The children saw it was ash, their hopes were dashed, and they died.

Also, in the great ocean there are merchants who encounter difficulties, their ship sinking and food lost. They see a pile of foam in the distance, suspecting it to be a shore. Hoping to reach it quickly, they prolong their lives. When they touch it and know it is not, their hopes are dashed and they die.
The Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢bhidharmahá¹›daya says:

In the great ocean there are large creatures that climb onto land, lay eggs, bury them in the sand, and return to the ocean. If the mother constantly thinks of the eggs, they will not be destroyed. If she loses her mindfulness, the eggs will perish.
This is not so, because it contradicts the meaning of food.
Can the food thought of by another sustain one's own body?
In reality, it should be said that the egg always thinks of the mother to prevent it from rotting, and if forgotten, it dies.
The thought of the mother arises in the stage of contact. All contaminated dharmas nourish existence.
How is it that the World Honored One speaks of food as only four?
Although this is so, speaking of four without error is based on the superior.
It is said that the first two foods nourish the body and its support, while the latter two foods attract future existence and give rise to future existence.
As for the support, it refers to the body with faculties. The food of material intake can benefit it.
As for the supported, it refers to the mind and mental factors. The food of contact can benefit them.
In this way, these two foods have the most superior ability to nourish existing existence.
As for future existence, it refers to future birth. The food of thought can attract it.
After being attracted by the food of thought, the power of the seeds of consciousness perfumed by karma gives rise to subsequent existence.
In this way, these two foods have the most superior ability to attract future existence.
Therefore, although all contaminated dharmas nourish and increase the three poisons, only the four foods are said to do so, because they are the most preeminent.
The first two foods are like a wet nurse, because they nourish the already born.
The last two foods are like a mother, because they give birth to the unborn.
Is all that is edible a food?
There are four alternatives.
The first alternative is that which is drunk or eaten as a condition for the destruction of the faculties and the great elements.
The second alternative is the other three foods.
The third alternative is that which is drunk or eaten as a condition for the nourishment of the faculties and the great elements.
The fourth alternative is that which is excluded from the above three.
In this way, each of the other three foods, contact, etc., should be understood as having four alternatives.
Can there be contact, etc., as a condition that nourishes the faculties and the great elements, but which is not a food?
Yes, namely, contact, etc., of a different stage and the pure path.
The body of one who has eaten and has abandoned eating is also called food, because it initially nourishes.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:
Both are able to act as nutriment during the two periods of time and are called nutriment.
The first is that at the time of the first meal it can remove hunger and thirst.
The second is that after digestion it nourishes the faculties and the great elements.
How many nutriments does each realm of rebirth possess?
All five realms of rebirth and four modes of birth possess four nutriments.
How can the realm of hells possess material food?
Are not iron balls and molten copper material food?
If that which can harm is also nutriment, then this contradicts the four alternatives stated above.
Also, the Prakaraá¹‡a-Å›Ästra says:
What is material food?
It is that which benefits the faculties and the great elements, and so on at length. Consciousness as nutriment is also like this.
This is said with reference to that which benefits and is called nutriment, and therefore there is no contradiction.

However, in the hells, although hot iron balls and so on can harm nutriment, they can temporarily relieve hunger and thirst, and because they obtain the characteristics of nutriment, they are also called nutriment.
Also, in the solitary hells, material food is like that of humans.
Therefore, all five destinies have four foods.
The World-Honored One said:
If one can give food to a hundred non-Buddhist ascetics who have abandoned desires, or if one can give food to a sentient being in JambudvÄ«pa, the latter's fruit is superior to the former.
What is meant by a sentient being in JambudvÄ«pa?
Some explain:
All those who dwell on JambudvÄ«pa and have a belly.
That explanation is unreasonable, because it uses the word one.

Moreover, giving food to the immeasurable sentient beings here is superior to giving food to a few non-Buddhist ascetics who have abandoned desires. What is so strange about comparing and praising that?
Some say:
They are bodhisattvas near the Buddha.
That is also unreasonable, because giving to them brings more blessings than giving to koá¹­is of arhats.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:
Those sentient beings have attained the factors conducive to penetration.

This name and meaning are also not appropriate, as there has never been a sutra or treatise that says one who obtains the factors conducive to penetration dwells in the Jeta Grove. You should know that this is only your own discrimination.
The bodhisattva in his final existence who dwells in the Jeta Grove is called an ordinary person.

This explanation is reasonable, because at that time the bodhisattva was the same as a detached sage, and therefore he was compared to that sage and praised as superior. Although the merit of giving to a bodhisattva is superior and boundless,
based on the previous comparison, it is said to be superior to a hundred. This must be the principle.
Later, the World-Honored One excluded that ordinary person and again compared the superiority and inferiority of the non-Buddhist path to that of the stream-enterer.
If it were not so, the World-Honored One would have compared that ordinary person to the stream-enterer.
The dependent origination and abiding of sentient beings have already been explained.
Now, the death, etc. that were previously mentioned should be properly discussed.
In what kind of consciousness and what kind of feeling are there death, rebirth, etc.?
In verse it is said:
Severing the roots of goodness and reconnecting with them, being free from passions, falling away from the fruits, dying, and being born,
It is admitted that these occur only in the mind consciousness. Dying and being born occur only in association with the faculty of indifference.
Neither occurs in samÄdhi, nor in the two mindless samÄdhis, nor in nirvÄá¹‡a.
When dying gradually, the final mind consciousness ceases in the feet, navel, and heart.
When not reborn in the lower realms or as a god, the vital force is cut off and water, etc., gushes out.

The Treatise says that severing the roots of goodness, reconnecting with the roots of goodness, being free from passions in the various stages and realms, falling away from freedom from passions, dying, and being bornâ€”in these six states, only mind consciousness, not other consciousnesses, is admitted by the Dharma.
You should know that the term â€œbeing bornâ€ also includes the initial linking of consciousness in the intermediate state.

Dying and being born occur only in association with the faculty of indifference, because a mind associated with indifference is unclear and sharp, while other feelings are clear and do not accord with dying and being born.
Also, these two states occur only in the distracted mind, not in samÄdhi, and there must be mind, not a mindless state.
The mind in samÄdhi does not have the meaning of dying and being born, because it is in a different realm and stage, is born of added effort, and is able to nourish and benefit.
Also, there is no meaning of death and rebirth without mind, because in the state without mind, life is definitely not damaged.
If the body that is the basis is about to change and be destroyed, one definitely returns to arouse the mind that belongs to the basis, and then life ends. There is no other principle.
Also, one without mind cannot receive rebirth, because there is no cause, and because there is no receiving rebirth apart from arousing the passions.

Although it is said that the death existence has a mind of the three natures, still, entering nirvana has only two indeterminate natures.ğŸ”½If it is said that the desire realm has the retribution of equanimity, then it is said that the mind entering nirvana in the desire realm also has the deportment and retribution of the indeterminate.
If it is said that the desire realm has no retribution of equanimity, then it is said that the mind entering nirvana in the desire realm only has the deportment and does not have the retribution.
Why is it that only the indeterminate can enter nirvana?
Because the power of the indeterminate is weak and accords with the cessation of mind.
In the state of death, in which part of the body does consciousness finally cease?
If one dies suddenly, the mental faculty and the body faculty suddenly cease altogether. If one dies gradually, the consciousness of humans and celestials goes downward.
Consciousness ceases in the feet and the heart, respectively. Those who fall into evil destinies are said to go downward. Their consciousness finally ceases in the feet.
If one goes to the human realm, consciousness ceases in the navel. If one is reborn in the heavens, consciousness ceases in the heart.
Arhats are said to be unborn. Their final mind also ceases in the heart.
Other masters say:
They cease in the head. At the very moment of death, because the body faculty ceases in the feet and other places, the mental faculty also ceases.
At the moment of death, the body faculty gradually ceases and suddenly ceases altogether in the feet and other places.
It is like placing a little water on a hot stone, gradually decreasing and disappearing, completely exhausted in one place.
Moreover, those who die gradually, at the moment of death, are often afflicted by the pain of severed vital parts.
There is no separate thing called a vital part, but there are certain joints in the body that, if touched, can cause death. These are called vital parts.
If the three elements of water, fire, and wind become excessively agitated, they are like sharp knives that touch the vital parts, and because of this, extreme pain arises. Before long, one will die.
It is not like cutting wood, which is called cutting off. Because it is like cutting off something without awareness, it is called cutting off.
Why does the earth element not have this function of cutting off?
Because there is no fourth internal calamity.
The three internal calamities are wind, heat, and moisture. Water, fire, and wind increase as appropriate and arise.
Some say:
This is similar to the three calamities of the external vessel.
This cutting off of vital parts does not exist in the heavens. However, when the celestial beings are about to die, five small signs of decline first appear:
First, the clothes and ornaments emit unpleasant sounds;
Second, the light of one's own body suddenly becomes dim;
Third, water droplets stick to the body when bathing;
Fourth, the nature is originally agitated but now stagnates on a single object;
Fifth, the eyes are originally still and now frequently blink.
These five signs do not necessarily mean death.
There are also five kinds of great signs of decline:
First, the clothes are stained with dust;
Second, the flower garlands wither;
Third, sweat comes out from both armpits;
Fourth, foul air enters the body;
Fifth, one does not enjoy one's original seat.
When these five signs appear, one will definitely die.
The World-Honored One, in the arising, abiding, and passing away of this sentient world, establishes three groups.
What are the three groups?
Verse:
The group of right nature, the group of wrong nature, and the indeterminate group.
The treatise says:
First, the group of definite right nature, second, the group of definite wrong nature, third, the group of indeterminate nature.
What is called right nature?
It is said in the sutra:
Completely cutting off greed, completely cutting off anger, completely cutting off delusion.
The complete and permanent elimination of all passions is called right nature.

Those who are determined are the noble ones. Noble ones are those in whom the path of the non-outflow has already arisen, because they are far from evil dharmas, they are called noble ones, because they have obtained the ultimate disjunction.
They are definitely determined to eliminate the passions, therefore they are called those of right determination.
Those who have already attained the factors conducive to liberation will also definitely attain nirvÄá¹‡a. Why are they not of right determination?
Because they may later fall into the category of those of wrong determination.
Also, because the time of attaining nirvÄá¹‡a is not definite, it is not like the maximum of seven rebirths for those of the stream-enterer stage, etc.
Also, because they have not yet been able to abandon wrong nature, they are not called those of right determination.
What is called wrong nature?
It refers to the hells, animals, and hungry ghosts. This is called wrong nature.
Those who definitely commit the five heinous crimes will definitely fall into hell, therefore they are called those of wrong determination.
Those of right and wrong determination are called those of undetermined nature.
They are so called because they can become either of the two, depending on two conditions.
